statement.p: Solve the system of equations

hint.p: Can you solve each equation separately? If so, then this is a simple system to solve!

solution.p: The first equation gives -2=2x, so x=-1. The second one is equivalent to 4=8y, so y=1/2.

statement.p: Solve the system of equations

hint.p: Can you solve each equation separately? If so, then this is a simple system to solve!

solution.p: The first equation gives -2=2x\text{,} so x=-1\text{.} The second one is equivalent to 4=8y\text{,} so y=1/2\text{.}

statement.p: Solve the system of equations

hint.p: Try adding or subtracting the two equations to find an equation with only one variable.

solution.p: If we add these two equations together, the 4y cancels giving 14x=0, so x=0. Setting x=0 in either of the two equations gives y=-1. Thus, the only solution is x=0 and y=-1.

DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context('Numeric');
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Solve the system of equations
[```\begin{cases} 4 + 10 x + 4 y=0\\ -4+4x-4y=0 \end{cases}```]
[`x=`][_]{0}{15} [@AnswerFormatHelp('numbers')@]*
[`y=`][_]{-1}{15} [@AnswerFormatHelp('numbers')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Try adding or subtracting the two equations to find an equation with only one variable.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION If we add these two equations together, the [`4y`] cancels giving [`14x=0\text{,}`] so [`x=0\text{.}`] Setting [`x=0`] in either of the two equations gives [`y=-1\text{.}`] Thus, the only solution is [`x=0`] and [`y=-1\text{.}`]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Solve the system of equations
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.

hint.p: Any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution to the system must satisfy both equations. In particular, the y-coordinates have to equal at the same time x^2+3x-5 and x+3. Use this to find the only possible values for x for which (x,y) could be a solution.

solution.p: Any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution must satisfy both equations. In particular, the y-coordinates of any solution have to both equal x^2+3x-5 and x+3. Thus, we have x^2+3x-5=x+3, which has solutions x=-4 and x=2. These are the only values of x for which (x,y) can satisfy both equations in the system of equations. Setting x=-4 in either of the two equations we find y=-1, so (x,y)=(-4,-1) is a solution (the only one with x=-4). Setting x=3 in either of the two equations we find y=5, so (x,y)=(2,5) is the only other solution.
Thus, the only solutions are (x,y)=(-4,-1) and (x,y)=(2,5)

[```\begin{cases} y=x^2+3x-5\\ y=x+3 \end{cases}```]

END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION Any pair of values [`(x,y)`] which is a solution must satisfy both equations. In particular, the [`y`]-coordinates of any solution have to both equal [`x^2+3x-5`] and [`x+3\text{.}`] Thus, we have
[```x^2+3x-5=x+3,```]
which has solutions [`x=-4`] and [`x=2\text{.}`] These are the only values of [`x`] for which [`(x,y)`] can satisfy both equations in the system of equations. Setting [`x=3`] in either of the two equations we find [`y=5\text{,}`] so [`(x,y)=(2,5)`] is the only other solution.
Thus, the only solutions are [`(x,y)=(-4,-1)`] and [`(x,y)=(2,5)`]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################

statement.p: Solve the system of equations
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.

hint.p: Note that you can isolate y in both equations. Note that any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution to the system must satisfy both equations. Use this to find the only possible values for x for which (x,y) could be a solution.

solution.p: Thus, we must have x^2-24=x-12, which has solutions x=-3 and x=4. These are the only values of x for which (x,y) can satisfy both equations in the system of equations. Setting x=-3 in either of the two equations we find y=-15, so (x,y)=(-3,-15) is a solution (the only one with x=-3). Setting x=4 in either of the two equations we find y=-8, so (x,y)=(4,-8) is the only other solution.

####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2019-02-18T16:09:56-05:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1(Active Learning Worksheet) ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1(Mathematics Consortium Working Group (MCWG)) ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(1.2.4) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context("Point"); $ans=Compute("(-3,-15), (4,-8)"); $evaluatorforans=$ans->cmp(showLengthHints => 1, partialCredit => 1, showHints => 1);
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Solve the system of equations
[```\begin{cases} x^2-y-24=0\\ y-x+12 = 0 \end{cases}```]
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.
[`(x,y)=`][_]{$evaluatorforans}{15} [@AnswerFormatHelp('points')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Note that you can isolate [`y`] in both equations. Note that any pair of values [`(x,y)`] which is a solution to the system must satisfy both equations. Use this to find the only possible values for [`x`] for which [`(x,y)`] could be a solution.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION Solving for [`y`] in both equations we find that
[```\begin{cases}y=x^2-24\\ y=x-12\end{cases}```]
Any pair of values [`(x,y)`] which is a solution must satisfy both of these equations. In particular, the [`y`]-coordinates of any solution have to both equal [`x^2-24`] and [`x-12\text{.}`]
Thus, we must have
[```x^2-24=x-12,```]
which has solutions [`x=-3`] and [`x=4\text{.}`] These are the only values of [`x`] for which [`(x,y)`] can satisfy both equations in the system of equations. Setting [`x=-3`] in either of the two equations we find [`y=-15\text{,}`] so [`(x,y)=(-3,-15)`] is a solution (the only one with [`x=-3`]). Setting [`x=4`] in either of the two equations we find [`y=-8\text{,}`] so [`(x,y)=(4,-8)`] is the only other solution.
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Solve the system of equations
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.

hint.p: Note that you can solve for y in the second equation. Since any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution to the system must satisfy both equations, then the y-value of any solution must be what the second equation tells you it should be. Plug this into the first equation to find the only possible values for x for which (x,y) is a solution.

solution.p: Solving for y in the second equation gives y=-x^2/2. Any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution to the system must satisfy y=-x^2/2, and so we can plug this into the first equation, giving 2x\left(-\frac{x^2}{2} \right)+\left(-\frac{x^2}{2} \right)\amp =\amp 0 -x^3-\frac{x^2}{2}\amp =\amp 0 -\frac{1}{2} x^2 (2 x + 1)\amp =\amp 0 so x=0 or x=-1/2. These are the only two possible values of x for which (x,y) may be a solution of the system (for some y). Setting x=0 in the second equation of the system we find y=0, so (x,y)=(0,0) is a solution (the only one with x=0). Setting x=-1/2 in the second equation of the system we find y=-1/8, so (x,y)=(-1/2,-1/8) is the only other solution.

############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Solve the system of equations
[```\begin{cases} 2xy+y=0\\ x^2+2y = 0 \end{cases}```]
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.
[`(x,y)=`][_]{$evaluatorforans}{15} [@AnswerFormatHelp('points')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Note that you can solve for [`y`] in the second equation. Since any pair of values [`(x,y)`] which is a solution to the system must satisfy both equations, then the [`y`]-value of any solution must be what the second equation tells you it should be. Plug this into the first equation to find the only possible values for [`x`] for which [`(x,y)`] is a solution.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION Solving for [`y`] in the second equation gives [`y=-x^2/2\text{.}`] Any pair of values [`(x,y)`] which is a solution to the system must satisfy [`y=-x^2/2\text{,}`] and so we can plug this into the first equation, giving
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} 2x\left(-\frac{x^2}{2} \right)+\left(-\frac{x^2}{2} \right)\amp =\amp 0 \\ -x^3-\frac{x^2}{2}\amp =\amp 0\\ -\frac{1}{2} x^2 (2 x + 1)\amp =\amp 0 \end{aligned}```]
so [`x=0`] or [`x=-1/2\text{.}`] These are the only two possible values of [`x`] for which [`(x,y)`] may be a solution of the system (for some [`y`]). Setting [`x=0`] in the second equation of the system we find [`y=0\text{,}`] so [`(x,y)=(0,0)`] is a solution (the only one with [`x=0`]). Setting [`x=-1/2`] in the second equation of the system we find [`y=-1/8\text{,}`] so [`(x,y)=(-1/2,-1/8)`] is the only other solution.
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Solve the system of equations
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.

hint.p: A solution to the system is a pair of values (x,y) which makes both equations true. Note that you can factor out a y in the second equation. What does the factored form tell you about the solutions to the second equation?

solution.p: Factoring out a 2y in the second equation gives 2y(1+x)=0, so either 2y=0 or 1+x=0 (or both). This shows that any solution (x,y) to the system must have y=0 or x=-1. Setting y=0 in the first equation gives \[10x+6x^2=0,\] which has solutions x=0 or x=-5/3. Thus, (x,y)=(0,0) and (x,y)=(-5/3,0) are two solutions (the only solutions with y=0). Setting x=-1 in the first equation gives -4+y^2=0, so y=\pm 2. Thus, (x,y)=(-1,-2) and (x,y)=(-1,2) are two more solutions (the only solutions with x=-1).
The solutions to the system are (0,0), (-5/3,0), (-1,-2) and (-1,2).

solution.p: Factoring out a 2y in the second equation gives 2y(1+x)=0\text{,} so either 2y=0 or 1+x=0 (or both). This shows that any solution (x,y) to the system must have y=0 or x=-1\text{.} Setting y=0 in the first equation gives \[10x+6x^2=0,\] which has solutions x=0 or x=-5/3\text{.} Thus, (x,y)=(0,0) and (x,y)=(-5/3,0) are two solutions (the only solutions with y=0). Setting x=-1 in the first equation gives -4+y^2=0\text{,} so y=\pm 2\text{.} Thus, (x,y)=(-1,-2) and (x,y)=(-1,2) are two more solutions (the only solutions with x=-1).
The solutions to the system are (0,0)\text{,} (-5/3,0)\text{,} (-1,-2) and (-1,2)\text{.}

statement.p: Find the partial derivative f_x for

hint.p: When finding a partial derivative all other variables are treated as constants.

solution.p: When we differentiate with respect to x, we think of y as a constant. Thus, f_x(x,y)\amp=\amp \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(x^2y-2x^2+3xy^2\right) \amp=\amp \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(x^2y\right)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(2x^2\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(3xy^2\right)\amp =\amp 2xy - 4x + 3y^2

############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context()->variables->add(y => ["Real"]); $ans=Compute("3-5*x^2+12*x*y");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Find the partial derivative [`g_y`] for
[```g(x,y)=3y-5x^2y+6xy^2+4```]
[`g_y=`][_]{$ans}{25} [@AnswerFormatHelp('formulas')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT When finding a partial derivative all other variables are treated as constants.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION When we differentiate with respect to [`y\text{,}`] we think of [`x`] as a constant. Thus,
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} g_y(x,y)\amp =\amp \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(3y-5x^2y+6xy^2+4\right)\\ \amp =\amp \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(3y\right)-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(5x^2y\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial y} \left(6xy^2\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(4\right)\\ \amp =\amp 3-5x^2+12xy \end{aligned}```]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2019-02-18T16:09:56-05:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1(Active Learning Worksheet) ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1(Mathematics Consortium Working Group (MCWG)) ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(1.2.12) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context("Matrix"); Context('Matrix')->variables->add(x=>'Real'); Context('Matrix')->variables->add(y=>'Real'); $M=Matrix([["2*x","x*y^2"],["-2","2*x+y"]]); Context("Numeric"); Context()->variables->add(y => ["Real"]); $determinant=Formula("4*x^2 + 2*x*y^2 + 2*x*y");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Find the determinant for
[```[$M]```]
determinant [`=`] [_]{$determinant}{10} [@AnswerFormatHelp('formulas')@]*
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT The determinant of
[```\pmatrix{a \amp b \\ c \amp d }```]
is [`ad-bc\text{.}`]
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} \det\pmatrix{2x \amp xy^2 \\ -2 \amp 2x+y} \amp = (2x)(2x+y)-(-2)(xy^2)\\ \amp = (4x^2+2xy)-(-2xy^2)\\ \amp = 4x^2 + 2xy + 2xy^2. \end{aligned}```]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Find the critical points of the following function.
The critical points are (input DNE if there are none):

hint.p: What is true about \nabla f(x,y) at a critical point?

solution.p:
A critical point of a function f(x,y) is a point where 
abla f(x,y)=\vec{0} or where 
abla f(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives f_x(x,y)\amp = -2-2xf_y(x,y)\amp = 4-8y, show that 
abla f(x,y) is defined everywhere, and 
abla f(x,y)=\vec{0} only when (x,y)=(-1,1/2). Thus, the only critical point is (-1,1/2).

BEGIN_PGML Find the critical points of the following function.
[```f(x,y)=9-2x+4y-x^2-4y^2```]
The critical points are (input DNE if there are none):
[`(x,y)=`] [_]{$ans}{15} [@AnswerFormatHelp('points')@]*
END_PGML

BEGIN_PGML_HINT What is true about [`\nabla f(x,y)`] at a critical point?

BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION A critical point of a function [`f(x,y)`] is a point where [`\nabla f(x,y)=\vec{0}`] or where [`\nabla f(x,y)`] is undefined. The partial derivatives
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} f_x(x,y)\amp = -2-2x\\ f_y(x,y)\amp = 4-8y, \end{aligned}```]
show that [`\nabla f(x,y)`] is defined everywhere, and [`\nabla f(x,y)=\vec{0}`] only when [`(x,y)=(-1,1/2)\text{.}`] Thus, the only critical point is [`(-1,1/2)\text{.}`]
END_PGML_SOLUTION

statement.p: Find the critical points of the following function.
The critical points are (input DNE if there are none):

hint.p: What is true about \nabla g(x,y) at a critical point?

solution.p:
A critical point of a function g(x,y) is a point where 
abla g(x,y)=\vec{0} or where 
abla g(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives g_x(x,y)\amp =10x+4y+4 g_y(x,y)\amp = 4x-4y-4, show that 
abla g(x,y) is defined everywhere, and 
abla g(x,y)=\vec{0} only at the points which are solutions the system of equations 10x+4y+4 \amp = 0 4x-4y-4 \amp = 0. If we add these two equations together, the 4y will cancel giving 14x=0, so x=0. Setting x=0 in either of the two equations gives y=-1. Thus, the only solution to the system is (x,y)=(0,-1). Thus, the only critical point is (0,-1).

statement.p: Find the critical points of the following function.

hint.p: What is true about \nabla h(x,y) at a critical point?

solution.p:
A critical point of a function h(x,y) is a point where 
abla h(x,y)=\vec{0} or where 
abla h(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives h_x(x,y)\amp= 6 x^2 + 10 x + y^2 h_y(x,y)\amp= 2xy+2y, show that 
abla h(x,y) is defined everywhere, and 
abla h(x,y)=\vec{0} only at the points which are solutions the system of equations 6 x^2 + 10 x + y^2 \amp= 0 2xy+2y \amp = 0. Factoring out a 2y in the second equation gives 2y(1+x)=0, so either 2y=0 or 1+x=0 (or both). This shows that any solution (x,y) to the system must have y=0 or x=-1. Setting y=0 in the first equation gives \[10x+6x^2=0,\] which has solutions x=0 or x=-5/3. Thus, (x,y)=(0,0) and (x,y)=(-5/3,0) are two solutions (the only solutions with y=0). Setting x=-1 in the first equation gives -4+y^2=0, so y=\pm 2. Thus, (x,y)=(-1,-2) and (x,y)=(-1,2) are two more solutions (the only solutions with x=-1).
Therefore, the solutions to the system are (0,0), (-5/3,0), (-1,-2) and (-1,2). These are the critical points.

solution.p: A critical point of a function h(x,y) is a point where \nabla h(x,y)=\vec{0} or where \nabla h(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives
show that \nabla h(x,y) is defined everywhere, and \nabla h(x,y)=\vec{0} only at the points which are solutions the system of equations

Factoring out a 2y in the second equation gives 2y(1+x)=0\text{,} so either 2y=0 or 1+x=0 (or both). This shows that any solution (x,y) to the system must have y=0 or x=-1\text{.} Setting y=0 in the first equation gives \[10x+6x^2=0,\] which has solutions x=0 or x=-5/3\text{.} Thus, (x,y)=(0,0) and (x,y)=(-5/3,0) are two solutions (the only solutions with y=0). Setting x=-1 in the first equation gives -4+y^2=0\text{,} so y=\pm 2\text{.} Thus, (x,y)=(-1,-2) and (x,y)=(-1,2) are two more solutions (the only solutions with x=-1).
Therefore, the solutions to the system are (0,0)\text{,} (-5/3,0)\text{,} (-1,-2) and (-1,2)\text{.} These are the critical points.

statement.p: The critical point (-5/3,0) is a
The critical point (0,0) is a
The critical point (-1,2) is a
The critical point (-1,-2) is a

hint.p: When you move away form the points, do the values of the contours always increase or decrease? Or are there directions in which they increase and others in which they decrease?

solution.p: When you move away form the (-5/3,0) in any direction, the contour values seem to always decrease. This indicates that (-5/3,0) is a maximum. A similar reasoning indicates that (0,0) is a minimum (all contour values increase away from the point).

Regarding the point (-1,2) note that if you move away from the point in the -\vec{i}+\vec{j} direction (or its direct opposite, the \vec{i}-\vec{j} direction) the values of the contours seem to decrease. However, if you move away from the point in the \vec{i}+\vec{j} direction (or its direct opposite, the -\vec{i}-\vec{j} direction) the values of the contours seem to increase. This indicates that (-1,2) is a saddle point. A similar reasoning shows that (-1,-2) is also a saddle point.

statement.p: Classify the critical points of the function using the second derivative test. f(x,y)=9-2x+4y-x^2-4y^2
The critical point (-1,1/2) is a

We know this for sure because (list all the valid reasons with commas):
D \gt 0 and f_{xx}(-1,1/2)\lt 0.
D \lt 0.
D \gt 0 and f_x(-1,1/2)\gt 0.
f_{xx}(-1,1/2)\gt 0.
f_x(-1,1/2)\lt 0.
Are there any other critical points?

hint.p: Find all the critical points and compute the value of D at each.

solution.p:
A critical point of a function f(x,y) is a point where 
abla f(x,y)=\vec{0} or where 
abla f(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives f_x(x,y)\amp = -2-2x f_y(x,y)\amp = 4-8y, show that 
abla f(x,y) is defined everywhere, and 
abla f(x,y)=\vec{0} only when (x,y)=(-1,1/2). Thus, the only critical point of f is (-1,1/2).

We compute D D=\det \pmatrix{f_{xx} \amp f_{xy} \\ f_{yx} \amp f_{yy}}=\det \pmatrix{-2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -8}=16, and see that D\gt 0 (at any point so in particular at (-1,1/2)), so we see that (-1,1/2) is a local maximum or a local minimum. To figure out which one it is, we can look at, for example, the concavity in x-direction by computing f_{xx}(-1,1/2) which gives f_{xx}(-1,1/2)=-2\lt 0. This indicates that f is concave down in the x-direction at (-1,1/2) and so (-1,1/2) is a local maximum.

############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $MultipleC= PopUp( ["Select choice", "maximum.","minimum.", "saddle point.", "...there is not enough information to decide."], "maximum.", ); $ans=Compute("1"); $evaluatorforans=$ans->cmp(showLengthHints => 1, partialCredit => 1, showHints => 1); $MultipleC2= PopUp( ["Select choice", "Yes","No"], "No", );
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Classify the critical points of the function using the second derivative test.
[```f(x,y)=9-2x+4y-x^2-4y^2```]
The critical point [`(-1,1/2)`] is a [_]{$MultipleC}{5}
We know this for sure because (list all the valid reasons with commas): [_]{$evaluatorforans}{15} [@AnswerFormatHelp('numbers')@]* 1. [`\newcommand{\gt}{>}D \gt 0`] and [`\newcommand{\lt}{<}f_{xx}(-1,1/2)\lt 0\text{.}`] 1. [`\newcommand{\lt}{<}D \lt 0\text{.}`] 1. [`\newcommand{\gt}{>}D \gt 0`] and [`\newcommand{\gt}{>}f_x(-1,1/2)\gt 0\text{.}`] 1. [`\newcommand{\gt}{>}f_{xx}(-1,1/2)\gt 0\text{.}`] 1. [`\newcommand{\lt}{<}f_x(-1,1/2)\lt 0\text{.}`]
Are there any other critical points? [_]{$MultipleC2}{5}
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Find all the critical points and compute the value of [`D`] at each.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION A critical point of a function [`f(x,y)`] is a point where [`\nabla f(x,y)=\vec{0}`] or where [`\nabla f(x,y)`] is undefined. The partial derivatives
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} f_x(x,y)\amp = -2-2x\\ f_y(x,y)\amp = 4-8y, \end{aligned}```]
show that [`\nabla f(x,y)`] is defined everywhere, and [`\nabla f(x,y)=\vec{0}`] only when [`(x,y)=(-1,1/2)\text{.}`] Thus, the only critical point of [`f`] is [`(-1,1/2)\text{.}`]
We compute [`D`]
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}D=\det \pmatrix{f_{xx} \amp f_{xy} \\ f_{yx} \amp f_{yy}}=\det \pmatrix{-2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -8}=16,```]
and see that [`\newcommand{\gt}{>}D\gt 0`] (at any point so in particular at [`(-1,1/2)`]), so we see that [`(-1,1/2)`] is a local maximum or a local minimum. To figure out which one it is, we can look at, for example, the concavity in [`x`]-direction by computing [`f_{xx}(-1,1/2)`] which gives [`\newcommand{\lt}{<}f_{xx}(-1,1/2)=-2\lt 0\text{.}`] This indicates that [`f`] is concave down in the [`x`]-direction at [`(-1,1/2)`] and so [`(-1,1/2)`] is a local maximum.
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Classify the critical points of the function using the second derivative test. g(x,y)=5x^2+4xy-2y^2+4x-4y
The critical point (0,-1) is a

We know this for sure because (list all the valid reasons with commas):
D \gt 0.
g_{xx}(0,-1)\lt 0.
D \lt 0.
g_x(0,-1)\gt 0.
g_{xx}(0,-1)\gt 0.
g_x(0,-1)\lt 0.
Are there any other critical points?

hint.p: Find all the critical points and compute the value of D at each.

solution.p:
A critical point of a function g(x,y) is a point where 
abla g(x,y)=\vec{0} or where 
abla g(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives g_x(x,y)\amp = 10x+4y+4 g_y(x,y)\amp = 4x-4y-4, show that 
abla g(x,y) is defined everywhere, and 
abla g(x,y)=\vec{0} only at the points which are solutions the system of equations 10x+4y+4 \amp = 0 4x-4y-4 \amp = 0. If we add these two equations together, the 4y will cancel giving 14x=0, so x=0. Setting x=0 in either of the two equations gives y=-1. Thus, the only solution to the system is (x,y)=(0,-1). Thus, the only critical point of g is (0,-1).

We compute D D=\det \pmatrix{g_{xx} \amp g_{xy} \\ g_{yx} \amp g_{yy}}=\det \pmatrix{10 \amp 4 \\ 4 \amp -4}=-56, and since D\lt 0 (at any point so in particular at (0,-1)), we see that (0,-1) is a saddle point.

statement.p: Classify the critical points of the function using the second derivative test. h(x,y)=2x^3+xy^2+5x^2+y^2
The value of D at (0,0) is . The critical point (0,0) is a
The value of D at (-5/3,0) is . The critical point (-5/3,0) is a
The value of D at (-1,-2) is . The value of D at (-1,2) is . The critical points (-1,2) and (-1,-2) are
Are there any other critical points?

hint.p: Find all the critical points and compute the value of D at each.

solution.p:
A critical point of a function h(x,y) is a point where 
abla h(x,y)=\vec{0} or where 
abla h(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives h_x(x,y)\amp = 6 x^2 + 10 x + y^2 h_y(x,y)\amp = 2xy+2y , show that 
abla h(x,y) is defined everywhere, and 
abla h(x,y)=\vec{0} only at the points which are solutions the system of equations 6 x^2 + 10 x + y^2 \amp = 0 2xy+2y \amp = 0.

Factoring out a 2y in the second equation gives 2y(1+x)=0, so either 2y=0 or 1+x=0 (or both). This shows that any solution (x,y) to the system must have y=0 or x=-1. Setting y=0 in the first equation gives \[10x+6x^2=0,\] which has solutions x=0 or x=-5/3. Thus, (x,y)=(0,0) and (x,y)=(-5/3,0) are two solutions (the only solutions with y=0). Setting x=-1 in the first equation gives -4+y^2=0, so y=\pm 2. Thus, (x,y)=(-1,-2) and (x,y)=(-1,2) are two more solutions (the only solutions with x=-1).
Therefore, the solutions to the system are (0,0), (-5/3,0), (-1,-2) and (-1,2). These are the critical points.
We compute D D \amp =\det \pmatrix{h_{xx} \amp h_{xy} \\ h_{yx} \amp h_{yy}} \amp =\det \pmatrix{12x+10 \amp 2y \\ 2y \amp 2x+2} \amp =24 x^2 + 44 x - 4 y^2 + 20.

At the point (0,0) we have D(0,0)=20\gt 0, so (0,0) is a local maximum or minimum. To figure out which one it is, we can look at, for example, the concavity in x-direction by computing h_{xx}(0,0) which gives h_{xx}(0,0)=10\gt 0. This indicates that h is concave up in the x-direction at (0,0) and so (0,0) is a local minimum.

At the point (-5/3,0) we have D(-5/3,0)=40/3\gt 0, so (-5/3,0) is a local maximum or minimum. We figure out which it is again by computing h_{xx}(-5/3,0)=-10\lt 0. This indicates that h is concave down in the x-direction at (-5/3,0) and so (-5/3,0) is a local maximum.
At the points (-1,-2) and (-1,2) we have D(-1,-2)=D(-1,2)=-16, and so both are saddle points.

solution.p: A critical point of a function h(x,y) is a point where \nabla h(x,y)=\vec{0} or where \nabla h(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives
show that \nabla h(x,y) is defined everywhere, and \nabla h(x,y)=\vec{0} only at the points which are solutions the system of equations

Factoring out a 2y in the second equation gives 2y(1+x)=0\text{,} so either 2y=0 or 1+x=0 (or both). This shows that any solution (x,y) to the system must have y=0 or x=-1\text{.} Setting y=0 in the first equation gives \[10x+6x^2=0,\] which has solutions x=0 or x=-5/3\text{.} Thus, (x,y)=(0,0) and (x,y)=(-5/3,0) are two solutions (the only solutions with y=0). Setting x=-1 in the first equation gives -4+y^2=0\text{,} so y=\pm 2\text{.} Thus, (x,y)=(-1,-2) and (x,y)=(-1,2) are two more solutions (the only solutions with x=-1).
Therefore, the solutions to the system are (0,0)\text{,} (-5/3,0)\text{,} (-1,-2) and (-1,2)\text{.} These are the critical points.
We compute D

At the point (0,0) we have D(0,0)=20\gt 0\text{,} so (0,0) is a local maximum or minimum. To figure out which one it is, we can look at, for example, the concavity in x-direction by computing h_{xx}(0,0) which gives h_{xx}(0,0)=10\gt 0\text{.} This indicates that h is concave up in the x-direction at (0,0) and so (0,0) is a local minimum.

At the point (-5/3,0) we have D(-5/3,0)=40/3\gt 0\text{,} so (-5/3,0) is a local maximum or minimum. We figure out which it is again by computing h_{xx}(-5/3,0)=-10\lt 0\text{.} This indicates that h is concave down in the x-direction at (-5/3,0) and so (-5/3,0) is a local maximum.
At the points (-1,-2) and (-1,2) we have D(-1,-2)=D(-1,2)=-16\text{,} and so both are saddle points.

BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION A critical point of a function [`h(x,y)`] is a point where [`\nabla h(x,y)=\vec{0}`] or where [`\nabla h(x,y)`] is undefined. The partial derivatives
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} h_x(x,y)\amp = 6 x^2 + 10 x + y^2\\ h_y(x,y)\amp = 2xy+2y , \end{aligned}```]

[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} 6 x^2 + 10 x + y^2 \amp = 0 \\ 2xy+2y \amp = 0. \end{aligned}```]
Factoring out a [`2y`] in the second equation gives [`2y(1+x)=0\text{,}`] so either [`2y=0`] or [`1+x=0`] (or both). This shows that any solution [`(x,y)`] to the system must have [`y=0`] or [`x=-1\text{.}`] Setting [`y=0`] in the first equation gives \\\[10x\+6x^2=0,\\\] which has solutions [`x=0`] or [`x=-5/3\text{.}`] Thus, [`(x,y)=(0,0)`] and [`(x,y)=(-5/3,0)`] are two solutions (the only solutions with [`y=0`]). Setting [`x=-1`] in the first equation gives [`-4+y^2=0\text{,}`] so [`y=\pm 2\text{.}`] Thus, [`(x,y)=(-1,-2)`] and [`(x,y)=(-1,2)`] are two more solutions (the only solutions with [`x=-1`]).
Therefore, the solutions to the system are [`(0,0)\text{,}`] [`(-5/3,0)\text{,}`] [`(-1,-2)`] and [`(-1,2)\text{.}`] These are the critical points.
We compute [`D`]
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} D \amp =\det \pmatrix{h_{xx} \amp h_{xy} \\ h_{yx} \amp h_{yy}}\\ \amp =\det \pmatrix{12x+10 \amp 2y \\ 2y \amp 2x+2}\\ \amp =24 x^2 + 44 x - 4 y^2 + 20. \end{aligned}```]
At the point [`(0,0)`] we have [`\newcommand{\gt}{>}D(0,0)=20\gt 0\text{,}`] so [`(0,0)`] is a local maximum or minimum. To figure out which one it is, we can look at, for example, the concavity in [`x`]-direction by computing [`h_{xx}(0,0)`] which gives [`\newcommand{\gt}{>}h_{xx}(0,0)=10\gt 0\text{.}`] This indicates that [`h`] is concave up in the [`x`]-direction at [`(0,0)`] and so [`(0,0)`] is a local minimum.
At the point [`(-5/3,0)`] we have [`\newcommand{\gt}{>}D(-5/3,0)=40/3\gt 0\text{,}`] so [`(-5/3,0)`] is a local maximum or minimum. We figure out which it is again by computing [`\newcommand{\lt}{<}h_{xx}(-5/3,0)=-10\lt 0\text{.}`] This indicates that [`h`] is concave down in the [`x`]-direction at [`(-5/3,0)`] and so [`(-5/3,0)`] is a local maximum.
At the points [`(-1,-2)`] and [`(-1,2)`] we have [`D(-1,-2)=D(-1,2)=-16\text{,}`] and so both are saddle points.
